headline: Super Easy Stir-Fried Cabbage
description: This cabbage stir-fry uses soy sauce and rice wine to enhance the natural sweetness in cabbage, cooks in only 5 minutes, and makes a simple side dish.

video.name: How to Make Super Easy Stir-Fried Cabbage

name: Super Easy Stir-Fried Cabbage

recipeInstructions.text: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium heat. Stir in garlic and cook until it begins to brown, 3 to 5 seconds.
Stir in cabbage until coated in oil; cover the wok and cook for 1 minute.
Pour in soy sauce; cook and stir for another minute. Increase heat to high and stir in Chinese cooking wine. Cook and stir until cabbage is tender, about 2 minutes more.

review.reviewBody: Kept it simple. Used Sesame seed oil, garlic, red pepper flakes, onion, black pepper. Stir Fried and topped with Crunch Garlic with Chili Oil for flavor. Bam! I recommend S&B Umami Topping Crunchy Garlic with Chili Oil.

Great idea and quick (using an induction stove). I needed more seasoning though and added a whole medium onion, fresh ground ginger, cumin seeds, dried methi leaves, red pepper flakes, and I replaced the cooking wine with rice vinegar simply because I didn’t have it, and lastly I used ghee for the cooking oil. I’ll try coconut next

I love the simplicity of this dish that also has a delicate elegance! I used dry sherry and a couple splashes of seasoned rice vinegar instead. It was satisfying on its own as a late simple supper. Going to pair it with country pork ribs tonight.
I prefer it made on a gas stove with a cast iron skillet. Ginger added with onions makes it nice & sweet!
Super easy to make and delicious.
Easy and simple way to enjoy cabbage. I made a few creative changes by adding jalapenos to make it a little spicy but overall this is a great starting point for easy stir fry cabbage

i toasted some leftover thanksgiving ham in some sesame oil before adding the garlic. i used lo sodium soy sauce because of the ham and used rice wine vinegar. came out very good. with a few minor adjustments, it can be made to taste exactly like fried rice. will experiment more! thanks.

Wish I could give this 3.5 stars. I used Mirin instead of Chinese cooking wine and seasame oil instead of oil. Even with the seasame oil, this dish was rather bland. It did nicely compliment my teriyaki salmon though. Since it provides bulk and is low calorie, I will probably make it again as part of our healthy diet push this year. I'll have to think on how to spice it up a bit more, --maybe some fresh ginger or teryiaki sauce.
I added some fresh broccoli , onion, and carrots. Excellent!

My family LOVES cabbage. This was GROSS to all of us. The wine/rice vinegar was not good to add at all. Thought I would make something different. 
 Sticking to what we already like.

Made this using Chinese cabbage from our garden. Stir-fried thinly sliced onion with the white ribs of the cabbage. I did not have Chinese cooking wine so I used Chardonnay. I served the stir-fry with center-cut loin pork chops and a side of brown rice pilaf with carrots, cranberries, slivered almonds (toasted) and parsley. My husband loved it.
It was perfect!

I use olive oil instead of vegetable oil, unless I have a few slices of bacon around! I never add soy sauce or wine, but I do add onion. It's a good, cheap side dish. I often prep the cabbage & onions ahead of time and freeze them in a gallon bag for quick weeknight meals.

Yummm. I hand shredded a head of cabbage. Which was a TON of cabbage. I doubled the Oil and soy sauce and used a TBS of rice vinegar instead of the wine. My garlic got browned and while I don’t particularly love that flavor it worked well with this dish.
Really delicious and simple!
We love it!

I used 1 large Vidalia onion sliced into thin half circle strips, a medium head of cabbage cut into small strips. Then cooked it all in 2 Tbs of EVO with a Tbs of Ghee, ¼ cup Merlot, 1 Tbs low sodium Soy sauce. Then finished it all with a Tsp of corn starch to make the remaining liquid adhere to the cabbage and onion. Seasoned with fresh ground pepper and Himalayan fresh ground salt to taste. Cooked it all on a Wok on medium high. It turned out delicious.
Any dry, white wine will do - I prefer dry sherry. A little cabbage goes a long way!

Added grated onion and carrot for flavour and sweetness..oh ya..a touch of teryaki.
Cant wait for the next time.
VG!!!! No Changes....
This recipe is easy and delicious! I'll be making this regularly...
So easy and simple. Will add to our rotation of side dishes.
Tasty and simple!
I have also used Bragg Liquid Aminos in place of the soy sauce. Good stuff!
Not impressed. Not much flavor
This was bland to me. I think next time I might nix the wine and add more soy sauce.

I followed the recipe with a few exceptions. I didn't have the Chinese wine so I used Mirin (sweeten Japanese sake) about a tbsp. and used a tbsp. of oyster sauce and this dish was to my liking. I used leftover chicken as well. This would make a good rice bowl but just on its own it was really good. I do not recommend using rice wine vinegar or any type of vinegar as it changes the taste of this dish ( unless this is the way you prefer it. ) If you do not have mirin, but have sake you can add a bit of sugar to it.
Definitely a keeper and will have cabbage haters swooning! I used chili oil instead vegetable oil and added a teaspoon of mirin and it was delicious.
I thought it was bland. I added more soy, rice wine vinegar, sugar, salt and pepper but it didn't help.
Excellent, easy, I love this!
This recipe is almost exactly the way my mother showed me how to stir fry cabbage except she adds a bit of grated ginger and 2 crushed red peppers when adding the garlic to the oil. Mmm-mmm-good!

This was so delicious. We have lots of cabbage in our garden this year and I have been looking for recipes to use it up. This is one recipe that I will be making often. I served this as a base to my stir fry, instead of rice or noodles. My husband is not a fan of cabbage, and he loved this. Thank you for sharing.

Oh my, oh my. Delicious. I did saute a vidalia first. I then carried out the recipe exactly. I even had the Chinese cooking wine. This recipe got a whole lot better when I took a bowl to my neighbor who is from Hong Kong and she loved it. Now that's what I call a 10 star recipe when my neighbor enjoyed MY Asian cooking when I only know how to cook Polish. Thank you, iken.
Solid recipe. I don't use the wine, and I add minced onion and a little ginger and black pepper.

Pretty good. My husband usually does a cabbage stir fry, but I was trying to pull dinner together with left over Chinese while he was busy. I used a minimal amount of canola oil and towards the end used a little bit of sesame oil and threw in some toasted sesame seeds also. I used rice vinegar as I had it on hand. I liked it. My husband usually adds more ingredients, but this worked and was quick and easy.
Very simple, fast and tasty. Used La Choy teriyaki sauce to supplement the soy sauce and rice vinegar instead of cooking wine.
I added a Tbs of sesame seed oil for flavor. Really good and fast stir fry.
Delicious! We subbed rice wine vinegar for the wine, added a little kale and some extra firm tofu (that we browned in a little oil) to make a full meal of it.

Was a bit dubious about a cabbage recipe but had some left over I wanted to use. Wow. Recipe is great. I added onions also and some fresh red chillies . Cooked it a bit longer until a bit crispy..mmmm yum. Happy.
Simple and amazing! I needed something to balance out my dinner of dumplings and rice, and this was the perfect thing. It'd be even better with a little shredded carrot for color.
I really liked this dish and it was super easy. I used apple cider vinegar because I didn't have anything else and at first thought it smelled weird, but wow, it was really good! Thanks!

I have no idea what chinese cooking wine is (and wouldn't try to find it for one dish) so used seasoned rice vinegar instead. Also added a few dashes of red pepper flakes. If you don't think you like cabbage, try this recipe. You will change your mind!!

I followed the instructions exactly, including using Shiitake mushrooms. I wanted to see if the type of mushroom would make a difference, but next time I will save the money and use button mushrooms. To garnish the dish, I added some cashews - Delish!

This was very good. I didn't measure anything, just threw the ingredients together until I thought it tasted good. I used butter, but oil would be good too. Used Japanese cooking wine because that's what I had. I liked the sweetness that it gave the cabbage, very good mixed with the saltiness of the soy sauce. I also added some rice vinegar because I love vinegar with cabbage. Oh, and extra garlic. I agree with the reviewer who compared this to an eggrole filling. Thanks!
This is a great way to use up some cabbage! Thanks for sharing!

A very versatile recipe! Add a small onion, or a 1/4 cup of sesame seeds; substitute mirin, rice vinegar, or apple cider vinegar; use sesame or peanut oil; add a teaspoon of white sugar, or a teaspoon of ground red pepper. Minor changes in this dish can affect the flavor in subtle ways to make it the perfect custom side dish to any Asian entrée! An excellent recipe! 5 STARS*****!
Any beginner can make this with success! Excellent and easy to make side dish!

Like others I used bagged cole slaw. Also added 1 TBSp of sugar with the soy sauce.
A perfect addition to the Asian chicken recipe.
Family didn't like this recipe at all. May be because I used savory cabbage. Didn't turn out very tasty.

Great recipe! I use the vegetable spray instead of oil, works great cuts the calories. I never have wine or anything like that so i omit that. If I don't have fresh garlic I use garlic pepper seasoning tastes fine. And I mix my soy sauce with equal parts oyster sauce and water. I also like to separately stir fry onions and add them to the finished cabbage. Add some steamed chicken for a main course!Super Healthy!

Something is definitely missing here. The only thing I can think of is that this must be Bok Choy and not your ordinary green cabbage. It was sweet to start with too! (I have been cooking since I was a teen - and I can serve up some gourmet meals...)

Simple & delicious! We loved this side dish w/ our Burmese curry & steamed rice dinner. The flavors of the ingredients are well balanced w/ the sweetness of the cabbage. I used 1/2 medium sized cabbage & it was perfect. Wouldn't change a thing about this recipe! Will definitely use again. Thanks so much for sharing!
Amazing recipe for being so simply. I substituted red wine vinegar, and it turned out great!
I thought this was excellent...easy and just the right amount of everything. I did sub the rice vinegar since I didn't have the wine and I added some toasted sesame seeds at the end. too easy!

Oh my this is good and easy to make. Didn't have the wine so substitued rice vinegar as others suggested. Used Napa cabbage cooked for about 3 min and kept warm in oven (at 190deg) while I stir fried the rest of dinner.. This is not a spicy dish and so it was a nice balance to the spicy pork and fried rice main course and also had a cucumber salad (rice vinegar style).
A friend of mine showed me his version of this. He added sliced onions to the cabbage, salt and pepper. It was awesome! It is amazing how simple a dish it is and how good it is!
I usually make this when I have left over coleslaw mix. It is quick and easy. I sometimes add a couple drops of sesame oil or some sesame seeds for variation.

A good complimenting side dish for other Asian cuisine. I used rice vinegar instead of wine and added about a tsp of white sugar. Using cole slaw mix with carrots and purple cabbage gave the recipe some additional color which was nice. Served with a little hoisin sauce on the side for dipping, the flavors reminded me of a vegetable egg roll minus the wrapper.
Okay, I was a little wierded out by the thought of eating straight cabbage, but this dish is amazing! I also tried it with apple cider vinegar in place of the wine, and it's great either way.
